abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Highway
            Project for Guinea was unsatisfactory. The project did not
            achieve its main objectives, its impact on institutional
            development was modest, sustainability is likely under the
            next highway project, and the performance of the Bank was
            satisfactory while the Borrower's was unsatisfactory.
            Several lessons can be learned from this project. First, the
            reversal from successful project implementation under the
            First Highway Project to very poor implementation under the
            Second Highway Project was due to a change in project
            organization and leadership. Second, consultants should keep
            the Bank aware of serious problems with a project instead of
            hiding them. Third, the Bank had a tremendous impact on
            reversing the trend of the project and greatly improving
            productivity. Fourth, measures should be implemented to
            avoid a repetition of the problems encountered under this
            project. Fifth, actions should be taken to deal with the
            continuing problems of establishing a resurfacing unit and
            improving the poor quality of patching. Finally, the
            Government should work to eliminate its difficulties with
            meeting local and foreign exchange contributions to project costs.
